transcript:
<transcript>d
<text start="0" dur="0.6"/>d
<text start="0.6" dur="3.47">Let's do a few examples multiplying fractions.</text>d
<text start="4.07" dur="4.975">So let's multiply negative 7 times 3/49.</text>d
<text start="9.045" dur="3.475"/>d
<text start="12.52" dur="2.88">So you might say, I don't see a fraction here.</text>d
<text start="15.4" dur="1.44">This looks like an integer.</text>d
<text start="16.84" dur="3.01">d
But you just to remind yourself that the negative 7 cand
</text>d
<text start="19.85" dur="6.76">be rewritten as negative 7/1 times 3/49.</text>d
<text start="26.61" dur="2.1">Now we can multiply the numerators.</text>d
<text start="28.71" dur="3.24">d
So the numerator is going to be negative 7 times 3.d
</text>d
<text start="31.95" dur="2.75">And the denominator is going to be 1 times 49.</text>d
<text start="34.7" dur="1.89">1 times 49.</text>d
<text start="36.59" dur="4.06">d
And this is going to be equal to-- 7 times 3 is 21.d
</text>d
<text start="40.65" dur="2.325">And one of their signs is negative,</text>d
<text start="42.975" dur="2.375">d
so a negative times a positive is going to be a negative.d
</text>d
<text start="45.35" dur="1.68">So this is going to be negative 21.</text>d
<text start="47.03" dur="2.06">You could view this as negative 7 plus negative 7</text>d
<text start="49.09" dur="1.37">plus negative 7.</text>d
<text start="50.46" dur="4.01">And that's going to be over 49.</text>d
<text start="54.47" dur="2.85">d
And this is the correct value, but we can simplify itd
</text>d
<text start="57.32" dur="4.83">more because 21 and 49 both share 7 as a factor.</text>d
<text start="62.15" dur="1.643">That's their greatest common factor.</text>d
<text start="63.793" dur="1.416">So let's divide both the numerator</text>d
<text start="65.209" dur="2.191">and the denominator by 7.</text>d
<text start="67.4" dur="3.41">Divide the numerator and the denominator by 7.</text>d
<text start="70.81" dur="2.66">And so this gets us negative 3 in the numerator.</text>d
<text start="73.47" dur="1.65">And in the denominator, we have 7.</text>d
<text start="75.12" dur="1.84">So we could view it as negative 3 over 7.</text>d
<text start="76.96" dur="3.11">Or, you could even do it as negative 3/7.</text>d
<text start="80.07" dur="1.65">Let's do another one.</text>d
<text start="81.72" dur="8.32">d
Let's take 5/9 times-- I'll switch colors more in this one.d
</text>d
<text start="90.04" dur="2.24">d
That one's a little monotonous going all red there.d
</text>d
<text start="92.28" dur="4.51">5/9 times 3/15.</text>d
<text start="96.79" dur="3.76"/>d
<text start="100.55" dur="1.67">So this is going to be equal to-- we</text>d
<text start="102.22" dur="1.75">multiply the numerators.</text>d
<text start="103.97" dur="2.37">So it's going to be 5 times 3.</text>d
<text start="106.34" dur="3.83">5 times 3 in the numerator.</text>d
<text start="110.17" dur="2.953">And the denominator is going to be 9 times 15.</text>d
<text start="113.123" dur="5.407">9 times 15.</text>d
<text start="118.53" dur="3.52"/>d
<text start="122.05" dur="2.65">d
We could multiply them out, but just leaving it like thisd
</text>d
<text start="124.7" dur="2.06">you see that there is already common factors</text>d
<text start="126.76" dur="1.74">in the numerator and the denominator.</text>d
<text start="128.5" dur="1.72">Both the numerator and the denominator,</text>d
<text start="130.22" dur="2.22">they're both divisible by 5 and they're</text>d
<text start="132.44" dur="2.26">both divisible by 3, which essentially tells us</text>d
<text start="134.7" dur="2.9">that they're divisible by 15.</text>d
<text start="137.6" dur="4.32">d
So we can divide the numerator and denominator by 15.d
</text>d
<text start="141.92" dur="2.35">So divide the numerator by 15, which</text>d
<text start="144.27" dur="2.75">is just like dividing by 5 and then dividing by 3.</text>d
<text start="147.02" dur="2.07">So we'll just divide by 15.</text>d
<text start="149.09" dur="1.42">Divide by 15.</text>d
<text start="150.51" dur="3.4">d
And this is going to be equal to-- well, 5 times 3 is 15.d
</text>d
<text start="153.91" dur="2.57">Divided by 15 you get 1 in the numerator.</text>d
<text start="156.48" dur="3.22">And in the denominator, 9 times 15 divided by 15.</text>d
<text start="159.7" dur="3.46">Well, that's just going to be 9.</text>d
<text start="163.16" dur="1.93">So it's equal to 1/9.</text>d
<text start="165.09" dur="1.06">Let's do another one.</text>d
<text start="166.15" dur="8.71">What would negative 5/9 times negative 3/15 be?</text>d
<text start="174.86" dur="1.5">Well, we've already figured out what</text>d
<text start="176.36" dur="3.949">positive 5/9 times positive 3/15 would be.</text>d
<text start="180.309" dur="1.791">So now we just have to care about the sign.</text>d
<text start="182.1" dur="2.99">d
If we were just multiplying the two positives, it would be 1/9.d
</text>d
<text start="185.09" dur="2.02">But now we have to think about the fact</text>d
<text start="187.11" dur="2.299">d
that we're multiplying by a negative times a negative.d
</text>d
<text start="189.409" dur="1.416">Now, we remember when you multiply</text>d
<text start="190.825" dur="3.295">a negative times a negative, it's a positive.</text>d
<text start="194.12" dur="1.57">The only way that you get a negative</text>d
<text start="195.69" dur="2">is if one of those two numbers that you're</text>d
<text start="197.69" dur="2.6">taking the product of is negative, not two.</text>d
<text start="200.29" dur="1.8">If both are positive, it's positive.</text>d
<text start="202.09" dur="2.822">If both are negative, it's positive.</text>d
<text start="204.912" dur="1.083">Let's do one more example.</text>d
<text start="205.995" dur="3.025"/>d
<text start="209.02" dur="3.6">d
Let's take 5-- I'm using the number 5 a lot.d
</text>d
<text start="212.62" dur="7.48">So let's do 3/2, just to show that this</text>d
<text start="220.1" dur="2.35">would work with improper fractions.</text>d
<text start="222.45" dur="6.82">3/2 times negative 7/10.</text>d
<text start="229.27" dur="4.45"/>d
<text start="233.72" dur="2.22">I'm arbitrarily picking colors.</text>d
<text start="235.94" dur="2.97">d
And so our numerator is going to be 3 times negative 7.d
</text>d
<text start="238.91" dur="3.59">3 times negative 7.</text>d
<text start="242.5" dur="4.29">And our denominator is going to be 2 times 10.</text>d
<text start="246.79" dur="1.1">2 times 10.</text>d
<text start="247.89" dur="4.66"/>d
<text start="252.55" dur="1.6">So this is going to be the numerator.</text>d
<text start="254.15" dur="4.33">Positive times a negative is a negative.</text>d
<text start="258.48" dur="3.53">3 times negative 7 is negative 21.</text>d
<text start="262.01" dur="1.65">Negative 21.</text>d
<text start="263.66" dur="1.89">And the denominator, 2 times 10.</text>d
<text start="265.55" dur="1.57">Well, that is just 20.</text>d
<text start="267.12" dur="2.59">So this is negative 21/20.</text>d
<text start="269.71" dur="3.4">d
And you really can't simplify this any further.d
</text>d
</transcript>`;d
